lines.line: It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.
lines.author: George Orwell

lines.line: I am an invisible man.
lines.author: Ralph Ellison

lines.line: Call me Ishmael.
lines.author: Herman Melville

lines.line: A screaming comes across the sky.
lines.author: Thomas Pynchon

lines.line: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of Light, it was the season of Darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair.
lines.author: Charles Dickens

lines.line: This is the saddest story I have ever heard.
lines.author: Ford Madox Ford

lines.line: Whether I shall turn out to be the hero of my own life, or whether that station will be held by anybody else, these pages must show.
lines.author: Charles Dickens

lines.line: It was a wrong number that started it, the telephone ringing three times in the dead of night, and the voice on the other end asking for someone he was not.
lines.author: Paul Auster

lines.line: Mother died today.
lines.author: Albert Camus

lines.line: The sky above the port was the color of television, tuned to a dead channel.
lines.author: William Gibson

lines.line: It was like so, but wasn't.
lines.author: Galatea 2.2

lines.line: All this happened, more or less.
lines.author: Kurt Vonnegut

lines.line: Ships at a distance have every man's wish on board.
lines.author: Zora Neale Hurston

lines.book: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
lines.line: There was a boy called Eustace Clarence Scrubb, and he almost deserved it.
lines.author: C. S. Lewis

lines.book: The Old Man and the Sea
lines.line: He was an old man who fished alone in a skiff in the Gulf Stream and he had gone eighty-four days now without taking a fish.
lines.author: Ernest Hemingway

lines.line: It was a pleasure to burn.
lines.author: Ray Bradbury

lines.line: What if this young woman, who writes such bad poems, in competition with her husband, whose poems are equally bad, should stretch her remarkably long and well-made legs out before you, so that her skirt slips up to the tops of her stockings?
lines.author: Gilbert Sorrentino

lines.line: If I am out of my mind, it's all right with me, thought Moses Herzog.
lines.author: Saul Bellow

lines.line: He was an inch, perhaps two, under six feet, powerfully built, and he advanced straight at you with a slight stoop of the shoulders, head forward, and a fixed from-under stare which made you think of a charging bull.
lines.author: Joseph Conrad

lines.line: The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.
lines.author: L.P. Hartley

lines.line: Psychics can see the color of time it's blue.
lines.author: Ronald Sukenick

lines.line: High, high above the North Pole, on the first day of 1969, two professors of English Literature approached each other at a combined velocity of 1200 miles per hour.
lines.author: David Lodge

lines.line: The cold passed reluctantly from the earth, and the retiring fogs revealed an army stretched out on the hills, resting.
lines.author: Stephen Crane

lines.line: I write this sitting in the kitchen sink.
lines.author: Dodie Smith

lines.line: Many years later, as he faced the firing squad, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was to remember that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice.
lines.author: Gabriel García Márquez

lines.line: The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents. We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far.
lines.author: H.P. Lovecraft

lines.line: The man in black fled across the desert, and the gunslinger followed.
lines.author: Stephen King

lines.line: For the heart, life is simple: it beats for as long as it can.
lines.author: Karl Ove Knausgård

lines.line: In a hole in the ground there lived a hobbit.
lines.author: J.R.R. Tokien
